[anxious] Look, I never thought I'd be using this stuff again, you know? [pause] All those years of training, the tactics, the... the understanding of how forces move through crowds. [sighs] I swore I was done with all that. But then I saw what they were doing to these kids—just kids with signs, for God's sake—and I couldn't just stand there. [frustrated] They had no idea how to protect themselves when the tear gas started. 

[quietly] So yeah, I started showing them things. Basic stuff, really. How to, um... how to recognize when a kettle formation is happening. [speeding up] Where the escape routes are before they close them off, how to move as a unit so nobody gets isolated. [pause] I taught them about the milk for the tear gas, how to make shields from traffic cones, the—[trailing off] 

[conflicted] Sometimes I wonder if I'm, err... if I'm making things worse somehow? [laugh] But then I see them helping each other, staying calm when the batons come out, and... [warm] These protesters, they're not fighters. They're teachers and students and, mmm, regular people who just want to be heard. [passionately] And they deserve to go home safe! 

[very quietly] My old unit would probably call me a traitor. [bitter] Using everything they taught me to work against them now. [pause] But protecting peaceful people from violence? [confidently] That's what I thought I was signing up for in the first place.

subject: Your guerrilla tactics knowledge helping protect peaceful protesters from police violence
